name: Securities Industry Essentials
description: Entry-level assessment of basic securities industry knowledge required for all aspiring securities professionals. Covers foundational concepts including market structure, product types, risk, and regulatory frameworks.
prerequisiteNote: None - can be taken without firm sponsorship
whoNeeds: All individuals seeking to enter the securities industry. Must be passed before or concurrent with any representative-level or principal-level qualification exam.
retakeWait: 30 days after first and second attempts, 180 days after third attempt
validity: 4 years if not associated with a FINRA member firm

topics.name: Knowledge of Capital Markets
subtopics: Types of economic markets and market structure
Regulatory entities and their functions (SEC, FINRA, MSRB, CBOE, state regulators)
Self-regulatory organizations (SROs) and their roles
Types of securities offerings (IPOs, secondary offerings, private placements)
Factors that impact markets (economic indicators, monetary/fiscal policy)
Business cycle and its impact on securities markets
Federal Reserve tools: open market operations, reserve requirements, discount rate
GDP, CPI, unemployment rate, and other key economic indicators
Global market factors: trade balances, currency exchange, geopolitical risks

topics.name: Understanding Products and Their Risks
subtopics: Equity securities: common stock, preferred stock, rights, warrants, ADRs
Debt securities: corporate bonds, government bonds, municipal bonds, money market instruments
Bond characteristics: coupon rates, yields, maturities, call features, ratings
Options: calls, puts, basic strategies, intrinsic and time value
Investment company products: mutual funds, closed-end funds, ETFs, UITs
Municipal fund securities: 529 plans, ABLE accounts, local government investment pools
Variable annuities and variable life insurance
Direct participation programs (DPPs) and limited partnerships
Real estate investment trusts (REITs)
Structured products and asset-backed securities
Risks: market risk, credit risk, interest rate risk, inflation risk, liquidity risk
Systematic vs. unsystematic risk
Currency risk, political risk, legislative risk
Reinvestment risk, prepayment risk, call risk
Risk/return trade-off and diversification

topics.name: Understanding Trading, Customer Accounts, and Prohibited Activities
subtopics: Types of accounts: individual, joint, corporate, trust, custodial (UGMA/UTMA), retirement
Account registration and documentation requirements
Customer identification programs (CIP) and anti-money laundering (AML)
Margin accounts: requirements, maintenance, Regulation T
Types of orders: market, limit, stop, stop-limit, GTC, day orders
Trade execution, settlement, and clearing processes
Primary and secondary markets, exchanges, and OTC markets
Roles of broker-dealers, market makers, and ECNs
Prohibited activities: insider trading, market manipulation, front-running
Churning, unauthorized trading, selling away
Suitability obligations and know-your-customer (KYC) rules
Communications with the public: advertising, correspondence, institutional/retail
Books and records requirements
SIPC coverage and limitations
Customer complaint handling and reporting

topics.name: Overview of the Regulatory Framework
subtopics: Securities Act of 1933: registration of new securities
Securities Exchange Act of 1934: regulation of secondary markets
Investment Company Act of 1940
Investment Advisers Act of 1940
FINRA registration and qualification requirements
Continuing education requirements (Regulatory Element and Firm Element)
Form U4 and Form U5
Statutory disqualification
SRO regulatory framework and rulemaking process

name: General Securities Representative
description: The General Securities Representative Examination qualifies an individual to sell a broad range of securities products including equities, bonds, options, mutual funds, variable annuities, DPPs, and more. Often referred to as the most important FINRA exam.
prerequisiteNote: SIE exam required; must be associated with and sponsored by a FINRA member firm
whoNeeds: Individuals who want to sell a broad range of securities including stocks, bonds, options, mutual funds, variable contracts, and direct participation programs.
retakeWait: 30 days after first and second attempts, 180 days after third attempt
validity: Must maintain registration with a FINRA member firm; 2-year window to re-register if terminated

topics.name: Seeks Business for the Broker-Dealer from Customers and Potential Customers
subtopics: Opening business development conversations with potential clients
FINRA rules on communications with the public (Rule 2210)
Retail communications, correspondence, and institutional communications
Approval and filing requirements for communications
Standards for content: fair and balanced presentation
Use of testimonials and endorsements
Social media and electronic communications compliance
Referral arrangements and solicitor relationships
Seminar and educational event compliance

topics.name: Opens Accounts After Obtaining and Evaluating Customers' Financial Profile and Investment Objectives
subtopics: New account documentation and agreements
Customer identification program (CIP) and AML requirements
Know your customer (KYC) and suitability requirements (FINRA Rule 2111)
Regulation Best Interest (Reg BI) obligations
Customer investment profile: financial status, tax status, investment objectives, time horizon, liquidity needs, risk tolerance
Account types: cash, margin, option, discretionary, advisory, wrap
Fiduciary accounts: trusts, estates, guardianships
Retirement accounts: IRAs (Traditional, Roth, SEP, SIMPLE), 401(k), 403(b), 457 plans
ERISA and qualified plan requirements
Corporate, partnership, and LLC accounts
Joint accounts (JTWROS, TIC, community property)
Custodial accounts (UGMA/UTMA)
Account transfers (ACATS process)
Margin account agreements: hypothecation, credit, loan consent

topics.name: Provides Customers with Information About Investments, Makes Suitable Recommendations, Transfers Assets, and Maintains Appropriate Records
subtopics: Equity securities: common stock characteristics, rights, voting, dividends
Preferred stock: cumulative, participating, convertible, callable
Rights offerings, warrants, and subscription privileges
American Depositary Receipts (ADRs) and foreign securities
Corporate bonds: secured, unsecured (debentures), convertible, callable, zero-coupon
Bond pricing, yields: nominal, current, YTM, YTC, yield to worst
Bond ratings: investment grade vs. high yield, rating agencies
Accrued interest calculations (30/360 and actual/actual)
U.S. government securities: T-bills, T-notes, T-bonds, TIPS, STRIPS
Agency securities: GNMA, FNMA, FHLMC, Federal Farm Credit
Municipal securities: general obligation vs. revenue bonds
Municipal bond analysis: feasibility studies, debt ratios, sources of revenue
Tax-exempt vs. taxable equivalent yield calculations
Industrial development bonds and private activity bonds
Money market instruments: CDs, commercial paper, bankers acceptances, repos
Options fundamentals: calls, puts, exercise, assignment, expiration
Options strategies: long/short calls and puts, covered calls, protective puts
Spreads: bull, bear, debit, credit, calendar spreads
Straddles and combinations
Options on indexes, interest rates, and currencies
Options suitability and risk characteristics
Mutual funds: open-end, classes (A, B, C shares), NAV, POP, sales charges
Breakpoints, rights of accumulation, letters of intent
Fund expenses: management fees, 12b-1 fees, expense ratios
Closed-end funds, exchange-traded funds (ETFs), unit investment trusts (UITs)
Variable annuities: accumulation and annuity phases, death benefits
Variable life insurance: whole, universal, variable universal
Direct participation programs (DPPs): oil/gas, real estate, equipment leasing
REITs: equity, mortgage, hybrid; publicly traded vs. non-traded
Hedge funds and alternative investments (accredited investor requirements)
Margin accounts: initial and maintenance requirements
Long margin: Regulation T, LMV, debit balance, equity calculations
Short margin: credit balance, SMV, equity calculations
Special memorandum account (SMA) and buying power
Day trading rules and pattern day trader requirements
Restricted and control securities (Rule 144, Rule 144A, Regulation S)
Fundamental analysis: financial statements, ratios, earnings analysis
Technical analysis: charts, trends, support and resistance, indicators
Modern portfolio theory: asset allocation, diversification, efficient frontier
Alpha, beta, standard deviation, Sharpe ratio
Tax implications: capital gains (short-term vs. long-term), wash sale rule
Cost basis methods: FIFO, specific identification, average cost
Gift and inheritance tax basis rules
Dividend and interest taxation, qualified vs. non-qualified dividends
Alternative minimum tax (AMT) considerations
Retirement plan distributions: RMDs, early withdrawal penalties, rollovers

topics.name: Obtains and Verifies Customers' Purchase and Sales Instructions and Agreements; Processes, Completes, and Confirms Transactions
subtopics: Order types: market, limit, stop, stop-limit, trailing stop
Order qualifiers: day, GTC, AON, FOK, IOC, NH, DNR
Trade execution on exchanges: auction market, specialist/DMM system
OTC market: market makers, bid/ask spread, OTCBB, Pink Sheets
Electronic communication networks (ECNs) and alternative trading systems (ATS)
Trade reporting: TRACE, TRF, OATS
Regulation NMS: order protection rule, access rule
Best execution obligations
Settlement dates: regular-way (T+1), cash, seller's option
Ex-dividend dates, record dates, payment dates
Confirmations and account statement requirements
DK (don't know) notices and trade corrections
Corporate actions: stock splits, reverse splits, stock dividends, mergers, tender offers
Proxy solicitation and voting requirements
SIPC coverage: amounts, limitations, excluded securities

name: Investment Company and Variable Contracts Products Representative
description: Qualifies an individual to sell mutual funds, variable annuities, variable life insurance, unit investment trusts, and municipal fund securities (such as 529 plans). A more limited license than the Series 7.
prerequisiteNote: SIE exam required; must be associated with and sponsored by a FINRA member firm
whoNeeds: Individuals who plan to sell only mutual funds, variable annuities, variable life insurance policies, unit investment trusts, and 529 plans. Often used in bank and insurance settings.
retakeWait: 30 days after first and second attempts, 180 days after third attempt
validity: Must maintain registration with a FINRA member firm

topics.name: Seeks Business for the Broker-Dealer from Customers and Potential Customers
subtopics: Prospecting methods and lead generation
Communications with the public: retail, correspondence, institutional
FINRA Rule 2210 content standards and approval requirements
Advertising mutual funds and variable products
Use of performance data and rankings in communications
Social media and electronic communications compliance
Filing requirements with FINRA for retail communications
Tombstone ads, summary prospectuses, and preliminary prospectuses

topics.name: Opens Accounts After Obtaining and Evaluating Customers' Financial Profile and Investment Objectives
subtopics: New account documentation and customer identification requirements
KYC obligations and suitability (FINRA Rule 2111)
Regulation Best Interest (Reg BI) obligations
Customer investment profile: financial situation, investment objectives, time horizon, risk tolerance
Account types: individual, joint, custodial, trust, retirement
IRA types: Traditional, Roth, SEP, SIMPLE
Employer-sponsored plans: 401(k), 403(b), 457 plans
529 college savings plans and Coverdell ESAs
UGMA/UTMA custodial accounts
Account transfer procedures (ACATS)

topics.name: Provides Customers with Information About Investments, Makes Suitable Recommendations, Transfers Assets, and Maintains Appropriate Records
subtopics: Investment company structure: open-end funds (mutual funds), closed-end funds, UITs
Mutual fund share classes: A, B, C shares and associated fee structures
Breakpoints, rights of accumulation, letters of intent
Net asset value (NAV) calculation, public offering price (POP), sales charges
Fund expenses: management fees, 12b-1 fees, total expense ratios
Prospectus requirements and delivery obligations
Fund investment objectives: growth, income, balanced, money market, index, sector
Exchange-traded funds (ETFs) vs. mutual funds
Variable annuities: separate account, subaccounts, accumulation and annuity units
Annuitization options: life, life with period certain, joint and survivor
Death benefit provisions and guaranteed minimum benefits
1035 exchanges and tax implications
Variable life insurance: whole life, universal life, variable universal life
Insurance features: death benefits, cash value, policy loans
529 plan features: qualified expenses, state tax deductions, gift tax treatment
ABLE accounts for individuals with disabilities
Systematic investment plans and dollar-cost averaging
Retirement plan distributions: RMDs, early withdrawal penalties, required beginning dates
Rollover rules: direct vs. indirect rollovers, 60-day rule
Tax treatment of mutual fund distributions: dividends, capital gains
Cost basis methods and tax-lot accounting
Suitability considerations for investment company and variable products
Risk factors: market, interest rate, inflation, credit, liquidity
Diversification and asset allocation concepts

topics.name: Obtains and Verifies Customers' Purchase and Sales Instructions, Processes and Completes Transactions
subtopics: Mutual fund purchase and redemption procedures
Forward pricing and NAV determination
Settlement procedures for investment company securities
Trade confirmations and account statement requirements
Exchange privileges within fund families
Systematic withdrawal plans
Anti-money laundering (AML) compliance
Suspicious Activity Reports (SARs) and Currency Transaction Reports (CTRs)
SIPC coverage and limitations
Customer complaint handling and reporting
Books and records retention requirements

name: Uniform Securities Agent State Law Examination
description: Tests knowledge of state securities regulations based on the Uniform Securities Act. Required in most states for securities representatives in addition to FINRA qualification exams. Administered by NASAA.
prerequisiteNote: No prerequisites; however, typically taken in conjunction with SIE and Series 7 or Series 6
whoNeeds: Securities agents (registered representatives) who transact business in a state. Required in most states alongside a FINRA qualification exam.
retakeWait: 30 days after first and second attempts, 180 days after third attempt
validity: Does not expire once registered; must re-take if not registered for 2+ years

topics.name: Regulation of Investment Advisers (State-Registered and Federal Covered)
subtopics: Definition of investment adviser under the Uniform Securities Act
State registration requirements for investment advisers
Exclusions from the definition of investment adviser
Exemptions from state registration
Federal covered advisers and notice filing requirements
Post-registration requirements: net capital, bonding, recordkeeping
Withdrawal and cancellation of registration

topics.name: Regulation of Investment Adviser Representatives
subtopics: Definition of investment adviser representative
State registration requirements for investment adviser representatives
Exclusions and exemptions from registration as an IAR
Supervision of investment adviser representatives
Termination and transfer of registration
Continuing education and qualification requirements

topics.name: Regulation of Broker-Dealers
subtopics: Definition of broker-dealer under the Uniform Securities Act
State registration requirements for broker-dealers
Exclusions from the definition of broker-dealer
Exemptions from state registration for broker-dealers
Post-registration requirements: net capital, bonding, recordkeeping
Withdrawal, cancellation, and succession of broker-dealer registration
Canadian broker-dealer provisions
Grounds for denial, suspension, or revocation of broker-dealer registration

topics.name: Regulation of Agents of Broker-Dealers
subtopics: Definition of agent under the Uniform Securities Act
State registration requirements for agents
Exclusions from the definition of agent
Exemptions from state registration for agents
Termination and transfer of agent registration
Supervision requirements for agents
Dual registration of agents
Grounds for denial, suspension, or revocation of agent registration
Continuing education and qualification requirements for agents

topics.name: Regulation of Securities and Issuers
subtopics: Definition of a security under the Uniform Securities Act
Registration of securities: coordination, qualification, notice filing
Exempt securities: government, bank, nonprofit, and others
Exempt transactions: isolated non-issuer, institutional, private placement
Federal covered securities and preemption of state registration
Stop orders and denial/suspension/revocation of securities registration
Effective dates and withdrawal of registration statements

topics.name: Remedies and Administrative Provisions
subtopics: Authority of the state Administrator
Administrative orders: cease and desist, deny, suspend, revoke
Judicial review of Administrator orders
Civil liabilities for violations: right of rescission
Statute of limitations for civil actions
Criminal penalties for willful violations
Subpoena power and investigative authority of the Administrator
Consent to service of process
Coordination with other state and federal regulators
Burden of proof in exemption claims

topics.name: Communication with Customers and Prospects
subtopics: Disclosure obligations: conflicts of interest, compensation, material information
Misrepresentations and omissions of material facts
Suitability of recommendations and know-your-customer obligations
Advertising and sales literature requirements under state law
Use of testimonials and endorsements
Performance reporting and presentation standards
Social media and electronic communications compliance
Correspondence and recordkeeping of client communications
Prospectus delivery and disclosure document requirements

topics.name: Ethical Practices and Obligations
subtopics: Fraudulent and prohibited practices under state law
Unethical business practices of broker-dealers and agents
Unethical business practices of investment advisers and their representatives
Fiduciary duties of investment advisers
Custody of client funds and securities
Advisory contracts: assignment, compensation, performance fees
Churning, unauthorized trading, and excessive markups
Insider trading prohibitions
Market manipulation: wash trades, matched orders, painting the tape
Lending to and borrowing from clients
Selling away and private securities transactions
Sharing in customer profits and losses
Gifts, gratuities, and business entertainment
Outside business activities and dual registration

name: Uniform Investment Adviser Law Examination
description: Qualifies an individual as an investment adviser representative (IAR). Covers economics, investment vehicles, investment strategies, ethics, and state/federal securities laws. Administered by NASAA.
prerequisiteNote: No prerequisites; does not require FINRA firm sponsorship
whoNeeds: Individuals who wish to act as investment adviser representatives (IARs). Can be taken without firm sponsorship, making it popular for fee-based financial planners and advisers.
retakeWait: 30 days after first and second attempts, 180 days after third attempt
validity: Does not expire once registered; must re-take if not registered for 2+ years

topics.name: Economic Factors and Business Information
subtopics: Basic economic concepts: supply and demand, business cycles, inflation, deflation
Monetary and fiscal policy: Federal Reserve tools, government spending, taxation
International economics: balance of payments, currency exchange rates, trade deficits
Financial reporting: balance sheet, income statement, cash flow statement
Financial ratios: liquidity, profitability, leverage, activity ratios
Quantitative methods: time value of money, present value, future value, NPV, IRR
Statistical concepts: mean, median, mode, standard deviation, correlation
Leading, lagging, and coincident economic indicators
Interest rate theories: expectations, liquidity preference, market segmentation
Yield curve analysis: normal, inverted, flat, and humped yield curves
GDP, CPI, PPI, unemployment rate interpretation

topics.name: Investment Vehicle Characteristics
subtopics: Cash and cash equivalents: T-bills, CDs, money market funds, commercial paper
Fixed-income securities: government, corporate, municipal, and agency bonds
Bond features: coupon, maturity, call/put provisions, sinking funds, convertibility
Bond valuation: pricing, yields (current, YTM, YTC), duration, convexity
Bond ratings and credit risk assessment
Equity securities: common stock, preferred stock, ADRs, warrants, rights
Stock valuation methods: P/E ratio, dividend discount model, book value
Investment company securities: open-end, closed-end, ETFs, UITs, interval funds
Mutual fund share classes, fees, and expenses
Options: basic concepts, strategies, rights and warrants
Alternative investments: real estate, REITs, hedge funds, private equity, commodities
Direct participation programs (DPPs)
Annuities: fixed, variable, equity-indexed, immediate, deferred
Insurance-based products: variable life, variable universal life
Structured products and derivatives basics
529 plans and education savings vehicles

topics.name: Client Investment Recommendations and Strategies
subtopics: Client profile analysis: financial status, goals, risk tolerance, time horizon, tax status
Asset allocation strategies: strategic, tactical, core-satellite
Modern portfolio theory: efficient frontier, optimal portfolios
Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM): beta, systematic risk, security market line
Alpha, Sharpe ratio, Treynor ratio, Jensen's alpha, information ratio
Diversification benefits and correlation analysis
Portfolio construction: growth, income, balanced, aggressive, conservative
Bond portfolio strategies: laddering, barbelling, bullet
Active vs. passive management strategies
Dollar-cost averaging and systematic investment approaches
Tax-efficient investing: tax-loss harvesting, municipal bonds, tax-advantaged accounts
Retirement planning: accumulation and distribution strategies
Social Security, Medicare, and pension considerations
Estate planning basics: wills, trusts, estate taxes, gift taxes
Charitable giving strategies: donor-advised funds, charitable trusts
Education funding strategies: 529 plans, Coverdell ESAs, UTMA
Special situations: concentrated stock positions, stock options, restricted stock
Risk management: hedging, insurance, emergency funds
Behavioral finance: cognitive biases, emotional biases, heuristics

topics.name: Laws, Regulations, and Guidelines, Including Prohibition on Unethical Business Practices
subtopics: Regulation of investment advisers under the Investment Advisers Act of 1940
State regulation of investment advisers and their representatives
Registration requirements: federal vs. state, AUM thresholds
Exemptions and exclusions from registration
Broker-dealer regulation under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934
FINRA rules and self-regulatory framework
Regulation of securities: registration, exemptions, and anti-fraud provisions
Securities Act of 1933: registration process and prospectus requirements
Fiduciary duty of investment advisers
Advisory contract requirements: assignment, compensation, termination
Performance-based compensation rules
Custody rules: qualified custodians, surprise audits, annual statements
Advertising rules for investment advisers: testimonials, performance presentation
Brochure rule (Form ADV Part 2) delivery requirements
Code of ethics and personal trading policies
Form ADV filing and updating requirements
Prohibited practices: front-running, churning, unauthorized trading
Insider trading: material nonpublic information, tipper/tippee liability
Anti-money laundering (AML) requirements
Privacy and data protection: Regulation S-P, safeguarding client information
Business continuity planning requirements
Record retention requirements
ERISA fiduciary requirements for retirement plan advisers

name: Uniform Combined State Law Examination
description: Combines the content of the Series 63 and Series 65 exams. Qualifies an individual as both a securities agent and an investment adviser representative. Administered by NASAA.
prerequisiteNote: Must have passed the Series 7 exam (or be registered as a General Securities Representative)
whoNeeds: Individuals who need both state securities agent and investment adviser representative registration. Requires Series 7 as a prerequisite, combining Series 63 and 65 content into one exam.
retakeWait: 30 days after first and second attempts, 180 days after third attempt
validity: Does not expire once registered; must re-take if not registered for 2+ years

topics.name: Economic Factors and Business Information
subtopics: Basic economic concepts: business cycles, inflation, deflation
Monetary policy: Federal Reserve actions and their impact on markets
Fiscal policy: government spending and taxation
International economic factors: currency, trade, globalization
Financial reporting: key financial statements and ratios
Quantitative methods: time value of money, NPV, IRR

topics.name: Investment Vehicle Characteristics
subtopics: Cash and cash equivalents: T-bills, money market, CDs, commercial paper
Fixed-income securities: types, features, pricing, yields, risks
Equity securities: common stock, preferred stock, ADRs
Investment companies: mutual funds, ETFs, closed-end funds, UITs
Derivative securities: options basics, rights, warrants
Alternative investments: REITs, DPPs, hedge funds, private equity
Insurance-based products: variable annuities, variable life insurance
Pooled investments and managed accounts

topics.name: Client Investment Recommendations and Strategies
subtopics: Client profile analysis and data gathering
Investment objectives: growth, income, capital preservation, speculation
Risk assessment: tolerance, capacity, and appropriate exposure
Asset allocation strategies and portfolio construction
Modern portfolio theory and diversification
Performance measures: alpha, beta, Sharpe ratio, standard deviation
Tax considerations in investment planning
Retirement planning strategies and products
Estate planning basics and wealth transfer
Education funding strategies
Active vs. passive management approaches
Dollar-cost averaging and rebalancing strategies
Behavioral finance: biases and their impact on decision-making
Risk management through insurance and hedging

topics.name: Laws, Regulations, and Guidelines, Including Prohibition on Unethical Business Practices
subtopics: State securities regulation under the Uniform Securities Act
Registration of persons: broker-dealers, agents, IAs, IARs
Exclusions and exemptions from state registration
Registration of securities: coordination, qualification, notice filing
Exempt securities and exempt transactions
Federal covered securities and preemption
Remedies and enforcement: Administrator authority and powers
Civil liabilities, criminal penalties, judicial review
Fiduciary obligations of investment advisers
Advisory contracts: requirements, fees, assignment, termination
Form ADV and disclosure requirements
Custody, discretion, and trading authority
Performance-based fees and hedge clause restrictions
Code of ethics and personal securities trading
Anti-fraud provisions under federal and state law
Prohibited practices: churning, front-running, market manipulation
Insider trading prohibitions and enforcement
AML requirements: CIP, SAR, CTR
Privacy and data protection (Regulation S-P)
Books, records, and business continuity requirements
Communications with the public and advertising rules
Solicitor and referral fee arrangements

name: General Securities Principal
description: Qualifies an individual to supervise and manage a broker-dealer's securities business. The primary supervisory license for branch managers and compliance officers at broker-dealer firms.
prerequisiteNote: Must have passed the SIE and a representative-level exam (typically Series 7); must be registered as a representative
whoNeeds: Individuals who supervise or manage the securities business of a broker-dealer, including branch office managers, compliance officers, and department supervisors.
retakeWait: 30 days after first and second attempts, 180 days after third attempt
validity: Must maintain registration with a FINRA member firm

topics.name: Supervision of Registration of the Broker-Dealer and Personnel Management Activities
subtopics: Broker-dealer registration requirements: SEC, FINRA, and state
Form BD filing and amendments
FINRA membership application process
Registration of associated persons: Form U4 and Form U5
Qualification examination requirements and waivers
Continuing education: Regulatory Element and Firm Element
Statutory disqualification and eligibility proceedings
Personnel management: hiring, supervision, and termination
Outside business activities (OBA) and private securities transactions

topics.name: Supervision of General Broker-Dealer Activities
subtopics: Supervisory systems and written supervisory procedures (WSPs)
Branch office and office of supervisory jurisdiction (OSJ) designation
Annual compliance and supervisory review meetings
CEO annual compliance certification
Books and records requirements (Rules 17a-3 and 17a-4)
Financial reporting requirements: FOCUS reports
Net capital rule compliance and early warning notification (Rule 15c3-1)
Customer protection rule (Rule 15c3-3)
Anti-money laundering (AML) program supervision
Suspicious activity reporting (SAR) and currency transaction reports (CTR)
Customer identification program (CIP) and OFAC screening
Business continuity planning (BCP) requirements
Cybersecurity and data protection obligations

Regulation S-ID: identity theft red flags
Communications with the public: review, approval, and filing
Advertising and sales literature review procedures
Social media supervision and policies
Customer complaint handling, investigation, and reporting
FINRA code of procedure: complaints, investigations, enforcement

Risk management and internal controls
Insider trading prevention: policies, restricted lists, watch lists
Information barrier procedures

topics.name: Supervision of Retail and Institutional Customer-Related Activities
subtopics: New account approval and review procedures

Options account approval and supervision

Breakpoint compliance and sales charge supervision
Gifts, gratuities, and entertainment policies
Political contributions: MSRB Rule G-37, pay-to-play
Registered representative supervision and review

topics.name: Supervision of Trading and Market Making Activities
subtopics: Best execution obligations and policies
Order handling and routing requirements
Regulation NMS compliance and order protection
Market making activities and requirements
Short selling rules: Regulation SHO, locate requirements
Regulation M: anti-manipulation during distributions
Trading halts, circuit breakers, and limit up-limit down

topics.name: Supervision of Investment Banking and Research
subtopics: Supervisory requirements for investment banking activities
Due diligence in public offerings
Filing requirements: SEC, FINRA, state

Municipal advisory activities and MSRB Rule G-42

name: Financial and Operations Principal
description: Qualifies an individual as a Financial and Operations Principal (FINOP). Responsible for a broker-dealer's financial reporting, net capital compliance, and customer protection rule obligations.
prerequisiteNote: No exam prerequisites; must be associated with a FINRA member firm
whoNeeds: Individuals responsible for a broker-dealer's back-office operations, financial reporting, net capital compliance, and regulatory financial filings. Every broker-dealer must designate at least one FINOP.
retakeWait: 30 days after first and second attempts, 180 days after third attempt
validity: Must maintain registration with a FINRA member firm

topics.name: Financial Reporting
subtopics: FOCUS Report: Form X-17A-5 preparation and filing
FOCUS Report: Part I (monthly) and Part II/IIA (quarterly/annual)
Annual audited financial statements and audit requirements
Independent public accountant selection and engagement
SEC Rule 17a-5 filing requirements and timelines
Compliance report and exemption report requirements
Notification requirements: capital deficiency, material inadequacy
Form BD amendments and regulatory updates
Form 17-H risk assessment filings

Balance sheet preparation and analysis
Income statement and statement of financial condition

topics.name: Operations, General Securities Industry Regulations, and Preservation of Books and Records
subtopics: Trade clearance and settlement processes
Clearing arrangements: self-clearing, fully disclosed, omnibus
NSCC, DTC, and FICC clearinghouse operations
Continuous Net Settlement (CNS) system
Corporate actions processing: dividends, splits, mergers, tender offers
Proxy distribution and processing
DK (don't know) trade processing

Record retention and electronic storage requirements
Business continuity planning for operations
FINRA registration and regulatory requirements
FinCEN filings: SAR, CTR, FBAR

subtopics: Net capital rule (SEC Rule 15c3-1): basic method and alternative method
Net capital computation: allowable and non-allowable assets
Haircuts on securities positions

name: Municipal Securities Principal
description: Qualifies an individual to supervise municipal securities activities at a broker-dealer. Covers MSRB rules, supervision of municipal securities underwriting, trading, and sales activities.
prerequisiteNote: Must have passed the SIE and Series 52 (Municipal Securities Representative) exam
whoNeeds: Individuals who supervise municipal securities activities at a broker-dealer, including municipal bond trading desks, underwriting departments, and municipal sales activities.
retakeWait: 30 days after first and second attempts, 180 days after third attempt
validity: Must maintain registration with a FINRA member firm

name: Investment Banking Representative
description: Qualifies an individual to participate in investment banking activities including advising on or facilitating debt or equity securities offerings, mergers and acquisitions, tender offers, financial restructurings, and other corporate transactions.
prerequisiteNote: SIE exam required; must be associated with and sponsored by a FINRA member firm
whoNeeds: Individuals who participate in investment banking activities such as advising on M&A, underwriting securities offerings, and structuring corporate transactions.
retakeWait: 30 days after first and second attempts, 180 days after third attempt
validity: Must maintain registration with a FINRA member firm

topics.name: Collection, Analysis, and Evaluation of Data
subtopics: Due diligence processes and procedures for investment banking engagements
Financial statement analysis: income statement, balance sheet, cash flow statement
Ratio analysis: profitability, liquidity, leverage, efficiency, and valuation ratios
Valuation methodologies: discounted cash flow (DCF), comparable company analysis, precedent transactions
Enterprise value and equity value calculations and bridge analysis
WACC (weighted average cost of capital) computation and capital structure analysis
LBO (leveraged buyout) analysis and financial modeling

Management assessment and corporate governance evaluation
Analysis of strategic alternatives for clients
Market and economic conditions affecting transactions
Research analyst reports and third-party data sources
Regulatory filings as sources of data (SEC EDGAR, 10-K, 10-Q, proxy statements)
Credit analysis and debt capacity assessment

topics.name: Underwriting/New Financing Transactions, Types of Offerings, and Registration of Securities
subtopics: Securities offerings: IPOs, follow-ons, secondary offerings, shelf registrations

topics.name: Mergers and Acquisitions, Tender Offers, and Financial Restructuring Transactions
subtopics: Types of M&A transactions: stock purchase, asset purchase, merger, consolidation
Hostile vs. friendly takeovers and negotiation dynamics
Tender offer rules: Schedule TO, Regulation 14D, Williams Act requirements
Proxy contests and activist investor strategies
Anti-takeover defenses: poison pills, staggered boards, white knights, crown jewels

Spin-offs, split-offs, carve-outs, and tracking stocks
Cross-border transactions and regulatory considerations
Regulatory requirements, compliance, and ethical standards in investment banking

name: Private Securities Offerings Representative
description: Qualifies an individual to act as a private securities offerings representative, selling securities in private placements under Regulation D and other exempt offerings rather than registered public offerings.
prerequisiteNote: SIE exam required; must be associated with and sponsored by a FINRA member firm
whoNeeds: Individuals who sell private placement securities (Regulation D offerings, private equity, venture capital interests, etc.) but do not need the full General Securities Representative (Series 7) qualification.
retakeWait: 30 days after first and second attempts, 180 days after third attempt
validity: Must maintain registration with a FINRA member firm

topics.name: Private Placement Regulations and Exemptions
subtopics: Securities Act of 1933: registration requirements and exemptions

topics.name: Customer Accounts, Suitability, and Due Diligence

topics.name: Regulatory Compliance and Business Conduct
subtopics: FINRA rules governing private placement activities

name: Research Analyst Qualification Examination
description: A two-part exam that qualifies individuals to function as research analysts who prepare research reports on equity securities. Part I covers analysis and valuation; Part II covers regulations and compliance. Both parts must be passed.
passingScoreNote: Part I: 73%; Part II: 74% (each part scored separately)
prerequisiteNote: Must have passed the SIE and Series 7 exams; must be associated with and sponsored by a FINRA member firm
whoNeeds: Individuals who prepare or approve research reports for distribution to customers. Required for equity research analysts at broker-dealers.
retakeWait: 30 days after first and second attempts, 180 days after third attempt
validity: Must maintain registration with a FINRA member firm

topics.name: Part I: Information and Data Collection
subtopics: Gathering financial data from public filings (10-K, 10-Q, proxy statements)
Industry and market research: trade publications, government data, databases
Company management interviews and site visits
Macroeconomic data collection: GDP, CPI, employment, interest rates
Competitor analysis and peer identification
Supply chain and customer analysis
Regulatory environment assessment
Corporate governance evaluation

topics.name: Part I: Data Verification and Analysis
subtopics: Financial statement analysis: income statement, balance sheet, cash flow
Quality of earnings analysis and accounting adjustments

Common-size analysis and trend analysis
Accounting standards: GAAP vs. IFRS differences, revenue recognition (ASC 606)
Lease accounting (ASC 842), inventory methods, depreciation
Pro forma financial statement preparation and adjustments
Statistical concepts: regression analysis, correlation, R-squared
Industry life cycle and competitive analysis (Porter's Five Forces, SWOT)

topics.name: Part I: Valuation and Forecasting
subtopics: Discounted cash flow (DCF) analysis: free cash flow to firm and equity

name: Operations Professional
description: Qualifies individuals performing operations functions at FINRA member firms who do not sell securities. Covers back-office functions including clearance, settlement, financial reporting, custody, and regulatory compliance.
prerequisiteNote: SIE exam required; must be associated with and sponsored by a FINRA member firm
whoNeeds: Individuals in operations roles at broker-dealers who do not engage in sales activities but handle clearance, settlement, custody, financial reporting, and other back-office functions.
retakeWait: 30 days after first and second attempts, 180 days after third attempt
validity: Must maintain registration with a FINRA member firm

topics.name: Professional Conduct and Ethical Considerations

name: Registered Options Principal
description: Qualifies an individual to supervise options trading activities at a broker-dealer. Covers listed options, OTC options, and the supervision of options account activity and compliance.
prerequisiteNote: Must have passed the SIE and a representative-level exam (typically Series 7); must be registered as a representative
whoNeeds: Individuals who supervise options trading activities, approve options accounts, and oversee options compliance at a broker-dealer.
retakeWait: 30 days after first and second attempts, 180 days after third attempt
validity: Must maintain registration with a FINRA member firm

topics.name: Supervise the Opening of New Options Accounts

name: General Securities Sales Supervisor
description: A two-part examination that qualifies an individual to supervise general securities sales activities, including options. Often taken by branch office managers. Series 9 covers options supervision; Series 10 covers general supervision.
prerequisiteNote: Must have passed the SIE and Series 7; must be registered as a General Securities Representative
whoNeeds: Individuals who supervise general securities sales activities and sales personnel at a broker-dealer, including branch office managers with options supervision responsibilities.
retakeWait: 30 days after first and second attempts, 180 days after third attempt
validity: Must maintain registration with a FINRA member firm

name: Municipal Securities Representative
description: Qualifies an individual to transact business in municipal securities. Covers municipal bond characteristics, underwriting, trading, customer accounts, and MSRB rules.
prerequisiteNote: SIE exam required; must be associated with and sponsored by a FINRA member firm or bank dealer
whoNeeds: Individuals who engage in municipal securities activities including underwriting, trading, sales, financial advisory, consulting, research, and investment advice for municipal securities.
retakeWait: 30 days after first and second attempts, 180 days after third attempt
validity: Must maintain registration with a FINRA member firm

subtopics: Types of municipal issuers: states, cities, counties, authorities, special districts

name: Municipal Advisor Representative
description: Qualifies an individual to act as a municipal advisor representative, providing advice to municipal entities and obligated persons on municipal financial products, the issuance of municipal securities, and investment of bond proceeds.
prerequisiteNote: Must be associated with and registered as a municipal advisor with the SEC and MSRB
whoNeeds: Individuals who provide advice to municipal entities regarding municipal financial products, the issuance of municipal securities, or investment strategies for bond proceeds.
retakeWait: 30 days after first and second attempts, 180 days after third attempt
validity: Must maintain registration with the MSRB

name: National Commodities Futures Examination
description: Qualifies an individual to sell commodity futures contracts, options on futures, retail off-exchange forex contracts, and swaps. Administered under NFA/CFTC jurisdiction rather than FINRA.
passingScoreNote: 70% (must pass each part separately: Part 1 minimum 70%, Part 2 minimum 70%)
prerequisiteNote: No prerequisites; must be sponsored by an NFA member firm
whoNeeds: Individuals who wish to solicit orders for commodity futures, options on futures, retail off-exchange forex, or swaps. Required for Associated Persons (APs) of commodity firms.
retakeWait: 30 days after first and second attempts, 180 days after third attempt

topics.name: Part 1: Market and Trading Knowledge
subtopics: Futures contract characteristics: standardization, delivery, expiration
Futures markets: exchanges, clearing organizations, settlement
Long and short futures positions
Margin: initial, maintenance, variation, performance bond

Types of orders: market, limit, stop, MIT, spread, contingency
Price limits, trading halts, and circuit breakers
Delivery process: first notice day, last trading day, delivery months
Cash settlement vs. physical delivery
Basis and basis risk: convergence, contango, backwardation
Hedging fundamentals: long hedge, short hedge, cross hedge
Hedging with agricultural commodities: grains, livestock, softs
Hedging with financial futures: interest rate, stock index, currency
Energy futures: crude oil, natural gas, refined products
Metals futures: gold, silver, copper, platinum
Speculation strategies and risk management
